Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add hijack=false parameter to OData get specific package" (#8161) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This will facilitate functional tests and end-to-end tests that require querying for package availability in DB instead of availability in V3 (search hijack). See the functional tests containing `hijack=true` for context. There is also one such case in the end-to-end tests. In short, there are many integration tests today that depend on checking for a package's availability prior to V3 indexing.

Essentially the difference when the new parameter is specified as `hijack=false`, you can see a package even before it has made its way the search service but _after_ validation is complete. This was previously achieved in various monitoring and testing places in our code via opaque hacks like adding an `$orderby` that can't be hijacked or adding `1 eq 1` to a `$filter`. 

Given the excellent performance of an ID+version lookup, it is acceptable to allow this non-hijacked query from a performance perspective. By the way, the package details page does this SQL query and much more.

An alternative approach could have been to carefully scrutinize each place that uses `hijack=false` and convince ourselves that moving from a non-hijacked to a hijacked query is acceptable from both a test coverage and flakiness perspective. My feeling is that this is not worth the risk. Also, in general we would be giving up from a testing/monitoring perspective on observing the state before a package is fully indexed in search but after it is validated.

I think that this PR (simple test hook) is better than the alternative. I think it is reasonable to have a programmatic way of fetching the DB state of a package and this is the simplest approach given our current various codebases. This will be undocumented on our public API surface area and not intended for external consumption, much like the internal `/search/query` endpoint on the search service.

Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2902.

# Gallery

Changes:
* Add functional tests on Gallery for Advanced Search (#8115) 
* Use protected configuration provider instead of reflection (WITHOUT DI) (#8132)
* Add command to compare PackageVulnerabilities to GitHub API (#7706) 
* Unbreak GitHubVulnerabilities2Db dependency injection (#8139) 
* Fix for: Malicious OData requests trigger exception monitoring (#8141) 
* Update range's vulnerability before entity update to fix index uniqueness error (#8140)

Progress:
* [x] Merge RI: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8147
* [x] Build: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3958957&view=results
* [x] Release: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_releaseProgress?_a=release-pipeline-progress&releaseId=772272
* [ ] DEV
* [x] INT
* [x] PROD

# GitHubVulnerabilities2Db

Changes:
* Unbreak GitHubVulnerabilities2Db dependency injection (https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8139)
* Fix PackageVulnerability indexing uniqueness error (https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8140)

Progress:
* [x] Merge RI: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8147
* [x] Build: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3958944&view=results

* [x] PROD

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Pack tells me it will exclude folder starting with dot, but does not" (#9921) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Version info

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): **NuGet.exe**

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): **5.6.0.6591**

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): **Win10 Version 2004 (OS Build20195.1000)**

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: **don't know**

## Description

"Nuget pack" is including my ".git" directory, even though it says it will exclude files and folders that start with a dot ('.'). Additionally, I have not been able to craft an exclude directive that will successfully exclude my .git directory.

### details

I keep my project in source control using git, so I have a .git directory and .gitignore file in the root of my project.

My project is very simple... just a PowerShell script module. So my "content" starts at the root directory.

Sample file layout:

```
PS E:\temp\nugetProblem2> dir -Recurse

    Directory: E:\temp\nugetProblem2

Mode                 LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                 -------------         ------ ----
d----           8/17/2020  8:10 PM                .git
-a---           8/17/2020  8:13 PM              4 .gitignore
-a---           8/17/2020  8:18 PM            309 nugetProblem.nuspec
-a---           8/17/2020  8:09 PM             52 ReadMe.txt

    Directory: E:\temp\nugetProblem2\.git

Mode                 LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                 -------------         ------ ----
-a---           8/17/2020  8:10 PM              4 shouldNotBePacked.txt

PS E:\temp\nugetProblem2>
```
When I run "nuget pack", it very clearly tells me:

```
WARNING: NU5119: File 'E:\temp\nugetProblem2\.gitignore' was not added to the package. Files and folders starting with '.' or ending with '.nupkg' are excluded by default.
```

And in fact it *does* exclude the ".gitignore" file. But it does **NOT** exclude the ".git" directory.

On top of that, I have not been able to come up with an "exclude" directive, either on the command line or in the .nuspec file, to exclude the ".git" directory.

### Repro steps, with sample project

Attached is a sample/dummy project that will reproduce the problem:
[nugetProblem.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/5087988/nugetProblem.zip)

**Repro steps:**
1. Extract the sample project.
2. In the root of the sample project directory, run "nuget pack".
3. Observe the warning message about how "Files and folders starting with '.'" will not be packed.
4. Rename the resulting .nupkg to .zip and open it up.

**Expected result:**
The .git folder should not be in the package.

**Actual result:**
The .git folder is in the package.

Events.RelatedBody: Many things (e.g.:  `UIActionEngine`, `NuGetUI`) in NuGet.PackageManagement.UI rely on `IVsSolutionManager`.  However, `ISolutionManager` isn't "remoting friendly."

Events.RelatedBody: This covers all of the various tasks that I'll have to do as part of the last week of my internship, including merging/passing my work onto others.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Automatic formatting with `dotnet format`" (#9917) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We should start enforcing code style through `dotnet format`. This will help us spend less time asking folks for miscellaneous style changes during code review, and catch it when we happen to miss something. Once the PR lands, it means in the future we'll stop having random formatting changes along with code PRs, hopefully.

As part of this task, we should also automate style verification on CI

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PMUI Update Tab in VS.Oe" (#9551) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Test:  PM UI Apex tests are flaky (UninstallPackageFromUI and so on)" (#9701) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The following  5 PM UI Apex tests are flaky recently:
```
SearchPackageFromUI
InstallPackageFromUI
InstallPackageToProjectsFromUI
UninstallPackageFromUI
UpdatePackageFromUI
```

UninstallPackageFromUI
Error message:
`System.TimeoutException : Timed out after 00:00:10 waiting for C:\school\ApexSolutions\TestCase2478\TestProject\packages.config did not exist within 00:00:10.`
Stack trace
```
   at Omni.Common.Waiter.ThrowIfExpired(String waitCondition)
   at Omni.Common.WaitFor.IsTrue(Func`1 predicate, TimeSpan timeout, Nullable`1 interval, String conditionDescription)
   at NuGet.Tests.Apex.NuGetUITestCase.WaitForFileExists(FileInfo file) in E:\A\_work\1\s\test\NuGet.Tests.Apex\NuGet.Tests.Apex\NuGetEndToEndTests\NuGetUITestCase.cs:line 161
   at NuGet.Tests.Apex.NuGetUITestCase.UninstallPackageFromUI() in E:\A\_work\1\s\test\NuGet.Tests.Apex\NuGet.Tests.Apex\NuGetEndToEndTests\NuGetUITestCase.cs:line 113
```

InstallPackageToProjectsFromUI 
```
 NuGet.Tests.Apex.NuGetUITestCase.InstallPackageToProjectsFromUI [FAIL]
        Expected True because newtonsoft.json/9.0.1 should be installed in TestProject, but found False.
        Stack Trace:
             at FluentAssertions.Execution.XUnit2TestFramework.Throw(String message)
             at FluentAssertions.Execution.TestFrameworkProvider.Throw(String message)
             at FluentAssertions.Execution.DefaultAssertionStrategy.HandleFailure(String message)
             at FluentAssertions.Execution.AssertionScope.FailWith(String message, Object[] args)
             at FluentAssertions.Primitives.BooleanAssertions.BeTrue(String because, Object[] becauseArgs)
          E:\A\_work\1\s\test\NuGet.Tests.Apex\NuGet.Tests.Apex\Utility\CommonUtility.cs(240,0): at NuGet.Tests.Apex.CommonUtility.AssertPackageInPackagesConfig(VisualStudioHost visualStudio, ProjectTestExtension project, String packageName, String packageVersion, ILogger logger)
          E:\A\_work\1\s\test\NuGet.Tests.Apex\NuGet.Tests.Apex\NuGetEndToEndTests\NuGetUITestCase.cs(93,0): at NuGet.Tests.Apex.NuGetUITestCase.InstallPackageToProjectsFromUI()
        Output:
          [test] info: Checking project newtonsoft.json
          [test] info: Exists: False
          [test] info: Package Manager Output Window Pane contents:  Added package 'Newtonsoft.Json.9.0.1' to folder 'C:\school\ApexSolutions\TestCase4302\packages'
          Added package 'Newtonsoft.Json.9.0.1' to 'packages.config'
          Executing script file 'C:\school\ApexSolutions\TestCase4302\packages\Newtonsoft.Json.9.0.1\tools\install.ps1'...
          Successfully installed 'Newtonsoft.Json 9.0.1' to NuProject
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
